If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will skillfully know the truth of ultimate meaning.
What are the ten?
First, because they accomplish the dharma of non-arising;
Second, because they accomplish the dharma of non-cessation;
Third, because they accomplish the dharma of indestructibility;
Fourth, because they accomplish the dharma of neither exiting nor entering;
Fifth, because they accomplish transcending the realm of words;ğŸ”½Sixth, because they accomplish the dharma of no verbal expression;
Seventh, because they accomplish the dharma of no conceptual proliferation;
Eighth, because they accomplish the dharma of indescribability;
Ninth, because they accomplish the dharma of quiescence;
Tenth, because they accomplish the dharma of the noble ones.
Why is it so?
Good man!
The principle of ultimate truth is originally indestructible.

Whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, it is originally thus, unborn and unceasing, neither coming out nor entering, not spoken by words, not expressed by words, free from all conceptual elaborations and grasping at realization.
Good man!
This ultimate truth is tranquil and still, inexpressible, only realized within by the sages themselves.
Moreover, good man!
This ultimate truth, whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, is originally indestructible.
For this reason, there are good men who give rise to right faith, leave the household life in purity, shave their beards and hair, and wear the monastic robe;
Having left the household life, they give rise to diligent effort, cultivate wholesome practices, like saving one's head from being engulfed in flames - seeking the Dharma is also like this.
Good man!

If one does not attain the truth of ultimate meaning, then the pure practices one cultivates will be empty and without benefit, and even if the TathÄgata appears in the world, it will be without benefit.
Therefore, good sons!
If there is a truth of ultimate meaning that can be spoken of, it is called a bodhisattva's understanding of the truth of ultimate meaning.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will skillfully understand the truth of ultimate meaning.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will skillfully understand dependent arising.
What are the ten?
First, knowing that all dharmas are empty;
Second, knowing that dharmas have no existence;
Third, knowing that dharmas are not real;ğŸ”½Fourth, knowing that dharmas are like reflections;
Fifth, knowing that dharmas are like shadows;
Sixth, knowing that dharmas are like echoes;
Seventh, knowing that dharmas are like illusions;
Eighth, knowing that dharmas do not remain for long;
Ninth, knowing that dharmas are in motion;
Tenth, knowing that all dharmas arise from conditions.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'This dharma is thus empty, thus nonexistent, thus unreal, thus like an image, like a shadow, like an echo, like an illusion, thus not lasting long, thus fluctuating, thus dependently arisen.
Although one understands that all born dharmas definitely do not abide and quickly go to destruction, one still establishes the dharma of birth, the dharma of cessation, and the dharma of abiding.
' And he further contemplates:
'From what conditions do these dharmas arise?
From what conditions do they cease?'

Having had this thought, he then knows that this dharma arises from ignorance, exists due to ignorance, and with ignorance as the forerunner and basis, relying on ignorance, the formations arise, and based on the formations, there is consciousness.

Because there is consciousness, name-and-form is established. Because name-and-form is established, the six sense bases exist. Because the six sense bases exist, all contacts arise. Because there is contact, feeling arises. Because of feeling, the foolish give rise to craving. Because craving oppresses, one gives rise to grasping. Because of grasping, one is bound to existence. Because of existence, there is birth. Because of birth, there is old age. Because of the dharma of old age, all beings die. Because of the dharma of death, there arise sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and despair. In this way, one attains the great mass of suffering.

Therefore, the wise should diligently strive to eliminate ignorance, destroy ignorance, uproot the roots of ignorance, and extinguish the dharmas of ignorance. Because of the cessation of ignorance, one can then eliminate the dharmas that are relied upon by those who lack wisdom.
It is just as when the life faculty ceases, all other faculties cease. When ignorance ceases, the dharmas that are relied upon by those who lack wisdom also cease, in the same way.
Why is it so?

Because there is no ignorance, there is no accumulation. All afflictions do not revolve through the destinies. Because the afflictions do not revolve through the destinies, one is able to extinguish the causes of birth and death and approach nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will be well versed in dependent arising.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will be able to understand themselves.
What are the ten?
First, bodhisattvas should observe themselves:
'In which family was this body of mine born?
Is it a brahmin family?ğŸ”½Is it a ká¹£atriya family?
Is it a householder family?
Or is it a high and wealthy noble family?
Or is it a lowly and humble family?
If I am born into a high and wealthy noble family, I should not rely on this condition to give rise to arrogance. Even if I am born into a lowly family,
I should give rise to this thought:
'It is because of the various karmas I created in the past that I was born into such a family.'
Then, because of this, he becomes disgusted with the world. Because of this disgust, he seeks to leave the household life.
Second, after the bodhisattva has left the household life, he should contemplate:
'For what purpose do I now seek to leave the household life?'
He then thinks to himself:
'I now leave the household life in order to liberate myself and also to liberate others, to attain liberation myself and also to cause others to attain liberation.
For this reason, I will never give rise to laziness and indolence.'
Third, the bodhisattva contemplates in this way:
'I have now left the household life in order to eliminate all unwholesome and evil dharmas without remainder.
If I have already eliminated all unwholesome dharmas, I will give rise to great joy and delight;
if I have not yet eliminated all unwholesome dharmas, I should strive diligently to quickly eliminate them.'
Fourth, the bodhisattva contemplates in this way:
'Now that I have gone forth, I should extensively cultivate and practice all wholesome dharmas.
If I have already been able to extensively cultivate all wholesome dharmas, my mind will be filled with joy and delight;
if I have not yet cultivated wholesome dharmas, I should be diligent and quickly cause them to increase.'
Fifth, the bodhisattva observes in this way:
'If I rely on a teacher, I will be able to increase all wholesome dharmas and destroy all unwholesome dharmas.'

For this reason, with regard to the preceptor, whether he has little learning or much learning, has wisdom or lacks wisdom, observes the precepts or violates the precepts, one should give rise to the thought of the Buddha, the Great Teacher.
Toward that teacher, with affection, faith, respect, and service, one should also respect and venerate the instructor in the same way as the preceptor.
Sixth, the bodhisattva observes in this way:
'If I rely on my preceptor, I will be able to perfect the factors of enlightenment that are not yet perfected, and be able to cut off all afflictions that have not yet been cut off.'
Therefore, towards that preceptor, one should respectfully serve him with a mind greatly delighted, as if he were one's own teacher.
That teacher is able to accept me with the right path and all wholesome dharmas, not accepting me with the wrong path and unwholesome dharmas.
Seventh, the bodhisattva observes in this way:
'Who is my teacher?'
He then carefully contemplates:

'The one with omniscience is my great teacher. He is clear about everything, has great compassion for the world, gives rise to the mind of great compassion, creates the great field of merit, and is able to be the teacher of gods, humans, asuras, and the world.'
For this reason, he gives rise to great joy and delight.
He further contemplates:
'If the Buddha, the World-Honored One, is my great teacher, I have truly gained great benefits.

I will follow the path of learning established by the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and practice and study according to his teachings for the rest of my life. I will follow his teachings without going against them.'
Eighth, the bodhisattva thinks like this:
'From whom should I beg for food?'
Having observed everywhere,

'I should go around begging from the houses of Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and commoners, enabling them to make great offerings of food, attain great results, accomplish great benefits, and possess great majestic virtue.
For this reason, I beg for food to enable them to attain the fruits.'
Ninth, the bodhisattva thinks like this:
'What thoughts do those Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and others have when they offer me food?'
Thus he carefully observes:
'Those Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and others will surely think of me as a Shramana, a Bhikshu, and a field of blessings, and therefore give me food.
I should now accumulate and practice the merits of a Shramana, a Bhikshu, and a field of blessings.'
Tenth, the Bodhisattva thinks like this:
'How can I escape from beginningless birth and death?'
Thus he carefully observes:
'First, if I attain the appearance of a Bhikshu, this is the first escape from birth and death;
Second, if I accomplish the merits possessed by a Bhikshu, this is the second escape from birth and death;
Third, if I can arouse diligence, abandon laziness, cultivate good conduct, and realize the nature of dharmas, this is the third escape from birth and death;
Fourth, if I thoroughly cultivate all practices, even becoming a Buddha to liberate sentient beings, this is the fourth escape from birth and death.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If bodhisattvas are able to always observe in this way, this is called knowing oneself well.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they know themselves well.
Moreover, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they know the world well.
What are the ten?ğŸ”½First, seeing arrogant people, they are able to humble themselves;
Second, seeing people with pride, they are able to be free from arrogance;
Third, seeing deceitful people, they are able to establish honesty;
Fourth, seeing people who tell lies, they speak the truth for them;
Fifth, seeing people who speak badly, they speak loving words for them;
Sixth, seeing people who are coarse and violent, they give rise to a gentle appearance;
Seventh, seeing people who are hateful and evil, they are able to be very patient;
Eighth, seeing people who are poisonous and harmful, they give rise to a mind of kindness;
Ninth, seeing people who are suffering and distressed, they give rise to compassion and pity;
Tenth, seeing stingy people and practicing generosity for them.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will be well-versed in the world.
Moreover, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will be born in the pure buddha lands.
What are the ten?
First, being endowed with pure precepts, unbroken and unadulterated, with faultless practice;
Second, practicing impartial mind, setting up impartial skillful means for all sentient beings;
Third, accomplishing vast wholesome roots, not being meager;
Fourth, being far removed from worldly fame, gain, and honor, and not being attached to them;
Fifth, being endowed with pure faith, without a doubting mind;
Sixth, arousing diligent effort, abandoning laziness;
Seventh, being endowed with the cultivation of meditation, without a distracted mind;
Eighth, cultivating much learning, without evil wisdom;
ninth, having sharp faculties and wisdom without dullness;
tenth, widely practicing kindness without a harmful mind.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will be born in the pure buddha-lands.
At that time, Bodhisattva Vemacitrin addressed the Buddha, saying:
How is it, World-Honored One, that one must cultivate all ten dharmas in order to be born,
or can one be born by cultivating one dharma without deficiency?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If one cultivates one dharma without interruption or destruction, without mixture or defilement, pure and clean, then one can accomplish the other dharma practices.
Good man!
The meaning here is that if one can cultivate all dharmas without deficiency, one will definitely be born in a pure buddha-land without doubt.
Moreover, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will not be defiled by the impurities of the womb.
What are the ten?
First, repairing the images of the TathÄgata;
Second, adorning and repairing old stÅ«pas;

Fourth, washing the Buddha's images with wonderful perfumed water;
Fifth, using mud and plaster to repair and sweep the ground around the TathÄgata's stÅ«pas;
Sixth, respectfully serving one's parents;
Seventh, respectfully serving one's teachers and preceptors, and those who practice the same pure conduct;
Eighth, although doing so, having no expectations;
Ninth, using these wholesome roots to dedicate them, wishing that by this goodness, it will universally cause all sentient beings to be born without being tainted by the impurities of the womb;
Tenth, with a deeply sincere and resolute mind.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will be born without being tainted by the impurities of the womb.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they can be either lay or ordained.
What are the ten?
First, attaining non-attachment;
Second, not dwelling in confusion;ğŸ”½Third, turning away from all objects;
Fourth, being far removed from all attachment to objects;
Fifth, not being tainted by the faults of objects;
Sixth, being able to respectfully cultivate and practice the training methods established by the TathÄgata, and furthermore being diligent and never complacent;
Seventh, even if one obtains only a small amount of food, drink, clothing, bedding, or medicine for illness, one is always content;
Eighth, following one's circumstances in obtaining robes and other necessities, being free from attachment;
Ninth, being disgusted with objects and always giving rise to fear;
Tenth, always diligently cultivating present quiescence.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they can be either lay or ordained.
